questions.question: A 47-year-old woman with a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) from diabetic nephropathy has been on hemodialysis for three years. She reports persistent back pain and changes in posture. An X-ray shows specific findings, shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old man with a history of heart failure and sensorineural hearing loss presents with worsening bone pain in his pelvis and lower back, fatigue, heaviness in his legs, tibial deformities, and occasional headaches. Laboratory tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels. Which radiographic finding is least likely associated with his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Champagne glass pelvis. Explanation: The scenario describes a case of Paget’s disease (osteitis deformans). The champagne glass pelvis (Option D) is typically observed in Achondroplasia and is not associated with Paget's disease. Paget’s disease (osteitis deformans): A non-neoplastic condition that is characterised by abnormal bone remodelling. Clinical features: Seen in elderly patients Presents with bone pain, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) (cranial nerve compression) Cardiac failure (hyperdynamic circulation) Raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP), but calcium and phosphorous levels are normal Radiological features: Osteoporosis circumscripta (Option A) : A circumscribed patch of osteoporosis in the skull. The cotton wool appearance of the skull (due to sclerosis) Tam O'Shanter sign : The skull's expansion and flattened base create the appearance of the skull tilting over the facial structures (due to the thickening of the frontal bone). (Option B) Blade of grass appearance or candle flame sign (Option C) : Flame-shaped lesion extending along the shaft of the bone. Picture frame vertebra: The vertebrae appear enlarged and have a thickened cortical bone due to excessive bone remodeling and disorganized osteoblastic activity. Ivory vertebra: Lincoln sign or Black Beard sign: Increased radiotracer uptake in the mandible gives it a distinctive black beard appearance that signifies abnormal bone metabolism in Paget’s disease. Banana fractures: Occur in a region of abnormal bone.

questions.question: Match the following skull findings according to their respective conditions. S.No Finding Condition 1. a) Paget’s Disease 2. b) Hyperparathyroidism 3. c) Sickle Cell Anemia 4. d) Multiple Myeloma 5. e) Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis

A 5-year-old boy presents with short stature and disproportionate limb length. His parents mention he has a broad forehead and has been slower to walk than peers & genetic testing reveals mutation in FGFR3 gene. Based on this presentation, which of the following radiological findings is least likely associated with his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Tam o'shanter sign Explanation: The clinical presentation along with FGFR3 gene mutation suggests Achondroplasia & tam o'shanter sign is not typically associated with this condition. It is associated with Paget’s disease. Achondroplasia Genetic condition caused by FGFR3 gene mutation featuring short stature and short proximal limbs, kyphosis, exaggerated lumbar lordosis Radiological findings: Trident hand sign (Option C) Pelvic champagne glass appearance (Option D) Tombstone appearance of the iliac blade Bullet nose vertebrae (Option A) Chevron sign

questions.question: A 28-year-old female presents to the emergency department with sudden pain in her right foot after playing soccer. She reports hearing a "snap" when she landed awkwardly while attempting to head the ball. On examination, swelling and tenderness are noted. An X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Jones fracture Explanation: The presented scenario, along with the X-ray findings, is diagnosed as a Jones fracture . Jones fracture Site Fracture of the base of the fifth metatarsal (extra-articular fracture) Mechanism It is caused by the pull exerted by the tendon of the peroneus brevis muscle

questions.question: Match the following fractures with their radiographs: 1. Bennett’s fracture a. 2. Rolando’s fracture b. 3. Gamekeeper fracture c. 4. Boxer’s fracture d.
A 25-year-old man presents with wrist pain and swelling following a fall while skiing and also reports difficulty moving his wrist. Based on the X-ray findings, what is the cause of his condition?

options.C: Radial styloid fracture leading to carpal instability

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Scapholunate ligament tear Explanation: The above radiograph shows Terry Thomas sign , i.e increased gap between the scaphoid and lunate bones which is indicative of Scapholunate ligament dissociation. This ligament tear commonly occurs after a fall onto an outstretched hand or may occur secondarily following a radial styloid fracture or a scaphoid fracture. Category Scapholunate dislocation Scaphoid

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with wrist pain and swelling after sustaining a fall on an outstretched hand. An X-ray is performed; what is the likely diagnosis based on the findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Barton’s fracture Explanation: The given X-ray depicts an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius, called Barton’s fracture. It is usually accompanied by a dislocation of the radiocarpal joint. Barton’s fracture Site Distal radius Mechanism of injury Fall on an outstretched hand Displacement Volar Barton’s fracture : Anterior displacement of the fracture fragment. Dorsal Barton’s fracture : Posterior displacement of the fracture fragment. Management Closed reduction Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF) X-ray Hutchinson fracture (Option A) , also called Chauffeur's fracture , is an intra-articular fracture of the radial styloid process at the distal radius caused by a fall or by direct impact in a car accident and commonly associated with carpal ligament injury. Colles fracture (Option B) is an extra-articular distal radius fracture characterised by dorsal angulation and displacement , caused by a fall on an outstretched hand and commonly present with Dinner-fork deformity. Smith fracture (Option C), also called Reverse-Colles fracture, involves a fracture of the distal radius with ventral displacement of the distal fragment. This fracture commonly occurs from a fall onto a flexed wrist, leading to a garden-spade deformity , along with wrist pain, swelling, and limited range of motion.

questions.question: A 28-year-old man presents with severe neck pain and limited head movement after falling from a 13-foot building. Examination reveals tenderness and restricted motion in the cervical spine. Based on his radiological findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Jefferson fracture Explanation: The depicted radiograph is a CT scan of the cervical spine showing a Jefferson burst fracture of the C1 vertebra (atlas). This fracture typically results from an axial load, such as a fall onto the head or a direct blow, causing a burst-type injury. Features: Lateral displacement of the lateral masses of C1 relative to C2. Fracture lines in the anterior and posterior arches of C1. Potential instability if there is transverse ligament rupture. Unstable fractures: Posterior fixation with pedicle screw system Chance fracture (Option A) is a seatbelt injury that results from a flexion-distraction mechanism . It involves disruption of the posterior column structures and is frequently associated with intra-abdominal injuries. Radiographic findings show a horizontal fracture through the posterior elements or disruption of the facet joints and spinous processes. Hangman's fracture (Option B) refers to a bilateral fracture of the pedicles of the C2 vertebra caused by hyperextension and axial loading of the cervical spine. The lamina, pedicles, and other parts of the posterior axis may also be involved in this type of fracture. Clay shoveller’s fracture (Option C) is an avulsion

questions.question: A 17-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of persistent pain and swelling above the left ankle, with constant and worsening discomfort, especially during physical activity. On examination, there is tenderness and a palpable mass over the lateral aspect of the distal fibula. An X-ray shows characteristic findings depicted in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Osteosarcoma Explanation: The clinical presentation and X-ray findings show increased density in the distal fibula due to tumour-induced bone production, along blood vessels creates a

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with localized pain and swelling in the anterior tibia. X-ray findings reveal the characteristics shown in the image. Based on these imaging features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Adamantinoma Explanation: The given clinical scenario, along with the X-ray finding showing lobulated lucent cystic lesions with disruption of the anterior cortex in the tibia, points towards Adamantinoma. Adamantinoma: ( Rare, low-grade malignant tumor) It primarily affects the tibial diaphysis in up to 90% of cases. Commonly occurs in individuals aged 20 to 40 years Typically present with pre-tibial pain, swelling , and occasionally fractures. Radiological Features: Expansive, lobulated lucent cystic lesion with disruption of the anterior cortex. Lytic Lesions : Characterized by multiple well-defined lucencies (Honeycomb-like Appearance) . Sclerosis : Interspersed sclerotic areas within the lytic regions. Extra-osseous Extension : 30% of cases Most Common Sites of Primary Bone Tumor: Epiphysis Metaphysis Diaphysis Chondroblastoma : Most common before puberty. Osteoclastoma/GCT(Giant Cell Tumor): Most common after

questions.question: A 10-year-old patient presents with symptoms suggestive of osteomyelitis. An MRI is performed, and the radiologist notes a finding indicative of acute osteomyelitis. Which of the following findings is considered pathognomonic for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bone marrow edema Explanation: The pathognomonic MRI finding of acute osteomyelitis is bone marrow edema , which appears as high signal intensity on T2-weighted images and low signal intensity on T1-weighted images & is one of the earliest radiological signs and appears within 24 hours (Earliest- Bone scintigraphy) The penumbra sign (Option A) (Ring enhancement due to granulation tissue) is pathognomonic for subacute osteomyelitis , especially in cases of Brodie's abscess. Sequestrum (Option C) refers to a piece of dead bone that has separated from healthy bone, commonly seen in chronic osteomyelitis. Involucrum (Option D) is the new bone formation that develops around the sequestrum, indicative of chronic osteomyelitis. Characteristic Radiological Features of Osteomyelitis: Imaging Modality Acute Osteomyelitis Subacute Osteomyelitis Chronic Osteomyelitis Plain Radiograph Minimal findings Possible soft-tissue swelling (5-7 days to appear) Lucent/sclerotic lesions Periosteal reaction Soft-tissue swelling Bone sclerosis Cortical thickening Sequestrum Cloaca Bone destruction Computed Tomography Not Useful Cortical/marrow abnormalities Abscess Periosteal reaction Edema Superior to radiograph for showing: Cloaca/sequestrum Periosteal new bone formation Abscess MRI Early bone marrow edema (low T1, high T2) Bone marrow/cortical changes Increased T2 in soft tissues Abscess formation; Post-gadolinium T1 outlines the abscess cavity clearly Enhanced resolution for Sequestra & Cloaca Outline abscess/sinus tracts Bone scintigraphy Increased uptake Diabetic Foot Osteomyelitis : T1-weighted images show low signal intensity in the marrow near an ulcer or sinus tract as the main indicator of osteomyelitis. Brodie’s Abscess : Common in children and presents as a centrally located lesion aligned vertically along the bone's axis, characterized by a sclerotic margin.

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy presents with mild left arm pain, which has worsened over the past few months, particularly after a recent fall while playing. There are no signs of infection or soft tissue involvement. An X-ray shows the findings depicted in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Simple Bone Cyst Explanation: The clinical scenario of left arm pain and swelling, along with an X-ray showing a well-defined, unilocular lytic lesion in the metaphysis of the left humerus, without infection or soft tissue involvement, suggests a diagnosis of a simple bone cyst. Fallen fragment sign:

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents with pain in the thigh and a noticeable deformity, as shown in the image. This deformity can be seen in all the following conditions except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Osteopetrosis Explanation: The deformity described is the shepherd's crook deformity of the femur, characterized by a bowing of the proximal femur. It results in a reduction of the femoral neck angle to nearly 90°, leading to a coxa vara deformity. This is commonly seen in conditions like Paget's disease of bone, osteogenesis imperfecta, and fibrous dysplasia . However, osteopetrosis (Option C) , a condition marked by excessive bone density, is not typically associated with this deformity. Osteopetrosis is a condition characterized by excessive bone density and is typically associated with Erlenmeyer flask deformity, also known as metaphyseal flaring.

questions.question: Which angle is typically used to measure the degree of spinal curvature?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cobb angle Explanation: The given X-ray finding suggests Scoliosis and Cobb Angle is used to assess the degree of curvature in this condition. Cobb Angle: It is measured by the intersection of perpendicular lines drawn to the end plates of the most tilted vertebrae in a spinal curve . A Cobb angle greater than 10° in the coronal plane indicates scoliosis. Codman Angle (Option A) is formed by the intersection of a line along the bone cortex and another line at the point where the periosteum is elevated. This is typically seen in conditions such as Ewing sarcoma and osteosarcoma. Ferguson Angle (Option C) is the angle formed between the plane of the sacral base (the upper surface of the sacrum) and the horizontal plane, used to assess lumbar lordosis.

questions.question: A 24-year-old male presents with persistent nocturnal pain in his right femur that is relieved by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). On examination, there is localised tenderness in the area & no history of trauma. The radiographic evaluation shows a small, well-defined lytic lesion with a central nidus. What is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) CT scan of the femur Explanation: The clinical presentation and radiographic findings suggest Osteoid osteoma , characterized by nocturnal pain that is relieved by NSAIDs. This benign bone tumor commonly affects young adults and is often located in the cortex of long bones, particularly the femur and tibia. Characterized by a nidus that secretes prostaglandins, leading to intense nocturnal pain. A CT scan is the investigation of choice (Osteoid osteoma is a cortical tumor. Hence, CT is superior to MRI which evaluates bone marrow & extent of tumors) , revealing a central radiolucent nidus accompanied by surrounding sclerosis and a Vascular groove sign (thin channel in the thickened bone around the nidus) It is managed by radiofrequency ablation. X-ray (Option A ) is used to diagnose fractures, joint conditions, tumours, and chest issues, as well as in dental assessments. It also guides treatment. Though an X-ray is the initial test for osteoid osteoma, CT provides better visualisation and confirms the diagnosis. MRI (Option B) is used to diagnose soft tissue pathologies, bone marrow conditions, and neurological disorders, but it is not preferred for osteoid osteoma as it can obscure the nidus. DEXA scan (Option C) measures bone mineral density to diagnose osteoporosis and assess fracture risk but is not preferred for osteoid osteoma as it does not provide detailed visualization of the lesion. Reference: Maheshwari Essential Orthopaedics, 5th Edition, Pages 235, 309 Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, 7th Edition, Pages 1285, 1971

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of bilateral wrist and knee pain, worse with inactivity and improving with movement. She reports morning stiffness lasting over an hour, fatigue, and low-grade fever. On examination, hand deformities are noted. All of the following are associated with her condition except:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Calcinosis cutis Explanation: The likely diagnosis is Rheumatoid arthritis (RA), a chronic inflammatory disease that typically presents with symmetrical joint involvement, prolonged morning stiffness, and systemic symptoms such as fatigue and low-grade fever. Symmetrical involvement of small joints, including the wrists, elbows, knees, ankles, metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, with sparing of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints. RA commonly leads to characteristic hand deformities such as Boutonniere deformity (Option B) (flexion of the PIP joint and hyperextension of the DIP joint) Swan neck deformity (Option C) ( hyperextension of the PIP joint and flexion of the DIP joint) Hitchhiker's thumb (or Z-deformity) (Option A) , involving a hyperextension of the thumb's first joint. Calcinosis cutis is the abnormal deposition of calcium salts in the skin and subcutaneous tissues, narrowing the joint spaces. It commonly occurs in CREST syndrome and is not related to Rheumatoid arthritis. Signs & radiological findings of Rheumatoid arthritis MCP joint’s subluxation Ball catcher's or Norgaard's view is used to evaluate the distal phalanx erosions. Hammer toe (due to extended DIP and flexed PIP of the toe) Hitchhiker's thumb (caused by extended IP and flexed MCP of thumb) Ulnar deviation of MCP Swan neck deformity (caused by extended DIP and flexed PIP) Boutonniere deformity (due to flexed PIP and extended DIP

questions.question: Match the following X-rays with their corresponding diagnoses X-rays Diagnosis 1. A. Achondroplasia 2. B. Tuberculosis 3. C. Acromegaly 4. D. Crest Syndrome 5. E. Psoriatic Arthritis

A 52-year-old man presents with chronic joint pain, stiffness, and mottling of teeth. He has a history of living in a rural area for several decades. His X-ray reveals increased bone density and calcification of ligaments. Based on these findings, which condition is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
"Scotty dog" sign is seen in?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Normal vertebral findings Explanation: The given X-ray of the lumbar spine shows a fracture of the pars interarticularis , commonly associated with Spondylolysis . This condition is characterised by the appearance of a "Scotty dog with a collar," which indicates a disruption of the Scotty dog appearance of normal lumbar vertebrae (Option A) Spine degeneration from wear and tear can cause back pain and may affect nearby nerves, resulting in radiating pain, numbness, or paresthesia along the corresponding dermatomes. This can lead to Stress fracture of Pars Interarticularis of vertebrae Spinal canal stenosis Spondylolisthesis Spondylolisthesis (Option B) occurs when a vertebra slips forward over the one below it, often leading to lower back pain and potential nerve compression. It is identified on an anterior-posterior (AP) X-ray by the inverted Napoleon hat sign in L5-S1 involvement and by the beheaded Scotty dog sign in a lateral view X-ray. Osteoporosis (Option C) is characterised by reduced bone mass and density, which increases the risk of fractures. It presents with a "codfish" appearance due to increased vertebral concavity, decreased bone density, cortical bone thinning, reduced trabecular patterns, and potential vertebral compression fractures.

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy, notably taller than his peers, presents with lower back pain and has a history of frequent shoulder dislocations. Scoliosis is noted, and an MRI has been recommended for further evaluation. Which of the following conditions aligns with the given radiological finding?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Marfan syndrome Explanation: Scalloping of the vertebrae refers to the abnormal concave deformity observed on either the anterior or posterior aspect of the vertebral bodies. Causes of Vertebral scalloping: Posterior scalloping Anterior scalloping Neural Tumors and cysts Schwannoma

questions.question: What is the most likely T-score that would confirm the diagnosis of osteoporosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) <-2.5 Explanation: A Dual Energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scan is primarily used to diagnose osteoporosis, assess fracture risk, and monitor drug therapy. The DXA scanner uses X-rays with two energy peaks, enabling the differential absorption of radiation by bone and soft tissue, which facilitates the calculation of bone mineral density (BMD). Interprets results using T-scores and Z-scores . T-score: It compares a patient's BMD to the average BMD of a healthy young adult of the same sex. It indicates how much the patient's bone density deviates from the optimal peak bone mass. WHO Criteria for Osteoporosis T score Interpretation >-1.0 (Option A) Normal BMD (bone mineral density) -1.0 to -2.5 (Option B) Osteopenia <-2.5 (Option C) Osteoporosis <-2.5 with fracture (Option D) Severe osteoporosis Z-score: It compares the patient's BMD to the average BMD of individuals of the same age and sex. It helps assess whether the bone density is within a normal range for that specific demographic group. Interpretation: A Z-score of -2.0 or lower may suggest significantly lower bone density compared to age-matched peers and may warrant further investigation into secondary causes of bone loss. Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, 7th Edition, Page 1099, 1100. David Sutton’s Textbook of Radiology and Imaging, Volume II, 7th Edition, Page 200.

questions.question: Match the following radiological findings with their associated condition. Radiological finding Condition 1. a) Paget's disease 2. b) Vertebral hemangioma 3. c) Osteopetrosis 4. d) Ankylosing spondylitis

A 16-year-old girl with sickle cell anemia was diagnosed at birth. She recently went to the hospital due to severe back pain that worsens with activity, as well as numbness and tingling in her legs, difficulty walking, and occasional weakness in her lower extremities. Which option accurately represents the radiographic findings of her spine for her condition? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Explanation: The radiographic findings in Sickle Cell Anemia reveal bone infarcts due ischemia of end arteries that result in H-shaped or Lincoln Log vertebrae. Vertebral appearances and their associated diseases: Vertebral appearances Seen in Radiological image Rugger Jersey Spine Renal osteodystrophy (Secondary hyperparathyroidism) Picture frame vertebra (Option A) Paget’s disease H-shaped appearance or Lincoln Log Vertebrae (Option C) Sickle cell anemia Biconcave Vertebrae (or) Codfish Vertebrae (or) Fish Mouth Vertebrae Osteoporosis Osteomalacia Sickle cell anemia (later stages) Vertebrae Plana (Option D) Trauma (most common cause in adults) Eosinophilic granuloma (Langerhans cell histiocytosis) Beaking of the Vertebrae Mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) Hurler's syndrome (anterior beaking or bullet-shaped vertebrae) (Option B) Hunter's syndrome Morquio's syndrome (middle beaking) Vertebral Scalloping Posterior scalloping is seen in: Dural ectasia (Marfan's syndrome or Neurofibromatosis) Neurogenic tumors (e.g., schwannoma) Anterior scalloping seen in: Aortic aneurysm. Lymphadenopathy of retroperitoneal and paraaortic lymph nodes (Tuberculosis)

questions.question: A 3-year-old child presents with fatigue, swollen and bleeding gums, bruising, joint pain, and dry skin. After a dietary assessment, it is found that the child has been consuming a diet low in fruits and vegetables. Which radiographic feature is most indicative of the probable condition?

options.D: Absence of white line of Frankel

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Wimberger’s Ring in the epiphysis Explanation: The scenario describes a case of Scurvy , which is characterised radiologically by the presence of Wimberger’s ring (ring epiphysis). Scurvy Rickets Deficient vitamin Vitamin C Vitamin D Reduced levels of Collagen Calcium Clinical features Increased capillary fragility Appearance of petechiae on the skin Delayed wound healing Bleeding gums Perifollicular hemorrhage Frog-like posture (semiflexion at hips and knees): Due to the inability to move limbs due to pain (pseudoparalysis). Scorbutic rosary (angular swellings at the costochondral junction arising due to subperiosteal bleed) Genu varum (bow-legs) or Genu valgum (knock-knees) Double-malleoli sign: The lateral malleolus of the ankles has two bony prominences instead of one. Waddling gait Frontal bossing Delayed closure of anterior fontanelle Craniotabes (soft skull bones with ping-pong ball consistency) Delayed dentition and enamel hypoplasia. Rachitic rosary (anterior chest wall has a beaded appearance due to swelling of costochondral cartilage junctions) Harrison sulcus: Depression along the lower border of the chest at the site of insertion of the diaphragm. Deformity of the hips: Coxa valga (femoral neck-shaft angle is increased) or coxa vara (femoral neck-shaft angle decreased) Radiological features Pencil-thin cortex A white line of Frankel is present (dense zone of provisional calcification at the growing metaphysis, giving a white line) Trummerfeld’s zone or Scorbutic zone (black area adjacent to the white line of Frankel, due to lack of mineralisation of osteoid) Wimberger's ring (epiphysis is small with a well-defined sclerotic margin, ring-shaped) Pelkan's spur (extensions at the metaphysis) Widening of the growth plate (Option A) . White Line of Frankel: Absent in active rickets (Option D) ; present in healing rickets after treatment. Splaying (widening) of bones. Cupping (concavity) (Option B) and fraying or (irregular margin) of bone ends. Protrusio acetabuli and triradiate deformity of the pelvis.
